alert.note: Alert for Iredell (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued August 28 at 9:29PM EDT until August 29 at 3:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 AM EDT TUESDAY FOR CENTRAL IREDELL COUNTY... At 929 PM EDT, Slow-moving thunderstorms are impacting central Iredell County from Scotts to Statesville to Cool Springs and producing torrential rainfall. Areas within the warned area have already seen 2-4 inches of rain with an additional 1-2 inches of rain likely. Flash flooding is imminent with significant flooding possible. This is a dangerous, life-threatening situation. People within the warned area are urged to exercise extreme caution on area roadways and stay away from all streams and adjacent low-lying areas for the next several hours. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life-threatening flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. Deeper flooding of common, flood-prone areas is likely, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Campgrounds adjacent to streams may see significant flash flooding, capable of lifting campers. Rapid stream flows over roadways is likely with culvert washouts possible. A few low-water crossings may become impassible. A few structures adjacent to streams may be inundated. Some locations that may experience flash flooding include... Statesville, Scotts and Cool Springs. The greatest threat is currently along and near Fourth Creek from Statesville and points east, including near Statesville Country Club, US 64, E Broad St, Bell Farm Rd, I-40, Old Mocksville Rd, and Beechwood Farm Rd. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
